title: 103_hr113
content: The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" aims to boost economic growth by offering a temporary tax credit to encourage the purchase of new domestic passenger vehicles. This credit allows purchasers to reduce the vehicle's purchase price by assigning the credit in exchange. The "Buy American Motor Vehicles Act of 1993" provides a tax credit for individuals purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles. The credit is a percentage of the vehicle's purchase price, with 15% for 1993 purchases and 7.5% for 1994 purchases. The maximum credit is $2,000 for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1993. The tax credit for purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles in 1993 is 15% of the vehicle's purchase price, and 7.5% for 1994 purchases. The maximum credit is $2,000 for taxable years ending on or before December 31, 1993, and $1,000 for years after that. Taxpayers can assign the credit to the dealer or manufacturer at the time of purchase. The tax credit for purchasing new domestic passenger vehicles in 1993 and 1994 allows taxpayers to assign the credit to the dealer or manufacturer at the time of purchase. The credit can be used against the tax imposed on the manufacturer. A new domestic passenger vehicle is defined as a passenger vehicle purchased by the taxpayer in the first retail sale. The term 'new domestic passenger vehicle' refers to a domestic vehicle purchased by the taxpayer in the first retail sale, produced by a domestic manufacturer in the US or Canada. The manufacturer must include specific information on the vehicle label as required by the Automobile Information Disclosure Act. The term 'domestic vehicle manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicles in the US or Canada. The manufacturer must include information on the vehicle label regarding its eligibility for the tax credit and the percentage of parts from domestic manufacturers. The term 'domestic vehicle manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicles in the US with production facilities in the country utilizing domestic parts. The term 'domestic parts manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicle parts with facilities in the US or Canada, utilizing domestic parts for at least 60% of the total value of all parts used in production. The term 'domestic parts manufacturer' refers to a manufacturer of motor vehicle parts with facilities in the US or Canada, not necessarily using domestic parts for production. The term 'related source' refers to a source affiliated with the production of motor vehicle parts, utilizing materials not exceeding 25 percent from related sources. The term 'related source' in the context of motor vehicle parts production refers to individuals or entities, including natural persons and corporations owned or controlled by Japanese citizens. The term 'own or control' in the context of motor vehicle parts production means holding at least 50 percent of the capital structure of a corporation. This ownership or control must be by natural persons who are citizens of Japan or by a corporation owned or controlled by Japanese citizens. The term 'own or control' in motor vehicle parts production means holding at least 50 percent of the capital structure of a corporation. This ownership or control requirement applies to corporations and other legal entities, with specific criteria for each. Affiliated domestic parts manufacturers are defined as having a related source holding at least 2.5 percent but less than 50 percent of the capital structure of the entity. Affiliated domestic parts manufacturers are defined as having a related source holding at least 2.5 percent, but less than 50 percent, of the capital structure of the entity. Purchase price and value definitions are provided for materials and components used in production of motor vehicles parts. The cost of materials, components, or parts used in the production of motor vehicles is determined for applying this title, including purchases involving related sources. The term 'United States' includes Puerto Rico and US possessions. Regulations must be prescribed by the Secretary within 60 days of enactment. The transfer price rules apply to the cost of materials in motor vehicle production. The term 'United States' includes Puerto Rico and US possessions. Regulations must be prescribed within 60 days of enactment, and the section does not apply to vehicles purchased after December 31, 1994. The amendments made by this section apply to vehicles purchased after December 31, 1992.
